abstract.text: The China Jinping Underground Laboratory, inaugurated in 2010, is an underground research facility with the deepest rock overburden and largest space by volume in the world.
The firstgeneration science programs include dark matter searches conducted by the CDEX and PandaX experiments.
These activities are complemented by measurements of ambient radioactivity and installation of low-background counting systems.
Phase II of the facility is being constructed, and its potential research projects are being formulated.
In this review, we discuss the history, key features, results, and status of this facility and its experimental programs, as well as their future evolution and plans.

body_text.text: An established approach to the search for new physics involves experimental studies of rare-occurrence events.
This typically requires low-background experiments with large target mass and elaborate shielding to suppress ambient radioactivity due to photons and neutrons.
Direct and induced effects due to cosmic rays, however, cannot be shielded.

Accordingly, such experiments should be performed in laboratories located underground, where a kilometer-scale rock overburden can effectively attenuate the cosmic-ray fluxes and their induced background.
Many underground facilities have been constructed around the world and house a range of diversified science programs [1].
Proton decays are generic predictions of Grand Unified Theories [2, pp.270-78] and attracted a great deal of interest in underground experiments and their techniques in the 1970s.

This early phase was followed by a series of important results on neutrino oscillations and mixings [2, pp.235-58] produced by underground experiments, which provided the first glimpse of physics beyond the Standard Model.
Ongoing and future generations of longbaseline neutrino beam experiments, which also involve massive underground detectors, will advance the study of the neutrino mixing matrix.
Also under way are experimental studies of neutrinoless double-β decay [2, pp.698-703], which aim to demonstrate that neutrinos are Majorana particles.

Beyond neutrino physics, underground laboratories are also home to an array of experiments performing direct searches for dark matter [2, pp.353-60] in the context of weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs, denoted by χ) and axions.
A new underground facility inaugurated in December 2010-the China Jinping Underground Laboratory (CJPL) [3,4]-will add high-quality laboratory space to this worldwide program.
In this review, we present an overview of the first-generation efforts (Phase I) at CJPL.
We discuss the first science programs, particularly CDEX (China Dark Matter Experiment; [5,6]) and PandaX (Particle and Astrophysical Xenon; [7]), and present their results.
We then describe the associated ambient background measurements and low-counting-rate facilities at CJPL [8].
We conclude with a discussion of the status and plans of Phase II [4], which is currently under construction.
II.
CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I
Since the 2000s, interest in constructing hydro-power facilities in the Yalong River area of Sichuan Province, China, has intensified [9].
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: In 2008, two 17.5-km-long traffic tunnels under Jinping Mountain were completed to facilitate the transport of construction materials.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The physics community in China immediately recognized the opportunities and potential of this development.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: By 2009, Tsinghua University and Yalong River Hydropower Development Company reached an agreement to jointly develop an underground laboratory facility-CJPL.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: Construction of Phase I of CJPL (CJPL-I) started in December 2009 near the center of one of the Jinping traffic tunnels, where the vertical rock overburden is maximal.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The inauguration of the facility took place in December 2010.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: Table I summarizes the key features of CJPL-I and presents a comparison between this facility and the similar Gran Sasso [10] and SNOLab [11] underground facilities.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: CJPL-I was built under Jinping Mountain with 2,400 m of rock overburden.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: It has drive-in access via a two-lane road tunnel with enough headroom for construction trucks.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: (The distances to the east and west ends of the tunnel entrance are 8.7 km and 8.8 km, respectively.)
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The main hall of CJPL-I, where the experiments were installed, has dimensions of 6.5 m (width) × 6.5 m (height) × 40 m (length), and accordingly the floor area is 260 m 2 .
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The facility is the deepest operating underground laboratory in the world.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The measured fluxes of residual cosmicray muons [12] at CJPL-I, and a comparison with various active underground laboratories, are displayed in Figure 2.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: We note for completeness that early cosmic-ray measurements had been performed at the Kolar Gold Fields in India, at locations with 2,760 m of rock overburden [13].
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: International access to CJPL is by regular flights from various hub cities in China to Xichang Domestic Airport.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The laboratory is located 90 km from the airport and is reachable by both highways and two-lane paved private roads shared with Yalong River Hydropower Development Company; the driving time is approximately 2 hours.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: A guest house, dormitory accommodation, canteens, and office space are available near the west entrance of the tunnel.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The bedrock surrounding CJPL is made of marble, with relatively low radioactivity from the contamination of 232 Th and 238 U isotopes (measurements of these isotopes and other background characterizations are discussed in Section V).
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The laboratory space is shielded from the bare rock by a 0.5-m-thick layer of concrete layer.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: Ventilation is provided by a 10-km-long, 55-cm-diameter pipeline that brings in fresh air from the west entrance of the tunnel at an air-exchange rate of 4,500 m 3 h −1 , allowing the radon level to be kept below 20 Bq m −3 .
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The laboratory is connected by internet cables at a bandwidth of 10 GHz.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The storage capacity of the computer servers, located in an exterior office, is up to 300 TB, with a transfer capacity of 10 GHz from the experiments.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The laboratory is equipped with surveillance CCD cameras and audiovisual alarm systems, and ambient conditions including temperature, pressure, humidity, and air composition are continually recorded.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: All recording devices are accessible from and can be monitored at remote sites.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The CJPL-I laboratory space is shared among three scientific programs: the CDEX [5] and PandaX [7] dark matter experiments and the Tsinghua University low-background facilities (THU-LBF) for low-radiopurity measurements [8].
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: The status and early results of these programs are discussed in the following sections.
body_text.section: II. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE I

body_text.text: III.
CDEX
Approximately one-quarter of the energy density of the Universe can be attributed to cold dark matter [2, p. 353], whose nature and properties are unknown.
body_text.section: III. CDEX

body_text.text: WIMPs are leading candidates.
body_text.section: III. CDEX

body_text.text: They interact with matter predominantly via elastic scattering with nuclei: χ + N → χ + N .
body_text.section: III. CDEX

body_text.text: The unique merits of CJPL make it an ideal location in which to perform low-background experiments on dark matter searches.
body_text.section: III. CDEX

body_text.text: Germanium detectors sensitive to sub-keV recoil energy are a possible means of probing so-called light WIMPs with mass 1 GeV < m χ < 10 GeV [14,15].
body_text.section: III. CDEX

body_text.text: This observation inspired detailed studies of p-type point-contact germanium detectors (pPCGe) with modular mass on the kilogram scale [16][17][18], which were followed by various experimental efforts [19][20][21][22][23].
body_text.section: III. CDEX

body_text.text: The scientific goal of CDEX [5], one of the two founding experimental programs at CJPL, is to pursue studies of light WIMPs with pPCGe.
body_text.section: III. CDEX

body_text.text: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments
The first-generation CDEX experiments adopted a baseline design [21,22] of single-element 1-kg mass scale pPCGe enclosed in NaI(Tl) crystal scintillator as an anti-Compton (AC) detector ( Figure 3).
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: These active detectors are surrounded by passive shielding made of oxygen-free high-conductivity (OFHC) copper, boron-loaded polyethylene, and lead.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The setup is further shielded by additional OFHC copper and lead layers.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The entire shielding and detector system is installed inside a room with interior dimensions of 4 m × 8 m × 4 m (height) and walls constructed with 1-m-thick polyethylene.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The pilot CDEX-0 measurement was based on a 20-g prototype germanium detector at a 177-eV ee threshold with an exposure of 0.784 kg • day [25].
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The CDEX-1 experiment adopted a pPCGe detector with a mass of 1 kg.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The first results [without the NaI(Tl) AC detector] were based on an analysis threshold of 400 eV ee with an exposure of 14.6 kg • day [26,27].
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: Subsequent data taking incorporated the AC detector.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: After suppression of the anomalous surface background events and measurement of their signal efficiencies and background leakage factors with calibration data [28,29], all residual events were accounted for by known background models.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The sensitivities were further improved with a longer exposure of 335.6 kg • day, and new constraints on spin-independent and spin-dependent χN couplings were derived [24].
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The results (Figure 4) represent the most sensitive measurements made with the point-contact high-purity germanium (HPGe) detector.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: Figure 5a shows the dark matter constraints on χN spin-independent cross sections, along with other selected benchmark results [20,[30][31][32][33][34][35][36].
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: In particular, the allowed region from the CoGeNT experiment [20] was probed and excluded by the CDEX-1 results.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The anomalous excess originated from the leakage of surface events into the bulk signal samples [28].
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: Figure 5b shows the constraints on χn spin-dependent cross sections, which also represent an improvement over published results in the light-WIMP region [30,37,38].
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The superb energy resolution of germanium detectors allows spectral structures to be resolved even at low energies, where atomic-physics effects can be important.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: This benefits studies of axion-like particles [39] because these particles' experimental signatures are usually manifested as peaks or steps in their energy depositions at the target.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: An analysis was performed with the CDEX-1 data, and constraints on axion-electron couplings (g Ae ) for solar ( Figure 5c) and dark matter axions ( Figure 5d) were derived [40].
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: In particular, the data represent an improvement over earlier results [41,42] for dark matter axions with mass below 1 keV.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: The CDEX-1 data set is currently being analyzed with a year-long exposure.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: Studies of annual modulation effects, as well as other physics channels, are under way.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: New data are being taken with an upgraded pPCGe with a lower threshold.
body_text.section: A. First-Generation CDEX Experiments

body_text.text: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals
The long-term goal of the CDEX program is a ton-scale germanium experiment (CDEX-1T) searching for dark matter and neutrinoless double-β decay (0νββ) [2, pp.698-703].
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: A pit with a diameter of 18 m and a height of 18 m has been built in Hall C of CJPL Phase II (CJPL-II) to house such an experiment ( Figure 6a).
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: Toward this end, the so-called CDEX-10 prototype has been constructed with detectors in an array structure with a target mass in the 10-kg range.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: CDEX-10 will provide a platform to study the many issues involving scaling up in detector mass and in improvement of background and threshold.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The detector array is shielded and cooled by liquid nitrogen (liquid argon may be investigated in the future, as it may offer an additional benefit of active shielding as AC detector).
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: Researchers are also pursuing other crucial technology acquisition projects that would make a ton-scale germanium experiment realistic and feasible.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: These include
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: (a) detector-grade germanium crystal growth;
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: (b) germanium detector fabrication;
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: (c) development of an ultralow-background, low-temperature, low-noise preamplifier; and (d ) production of electroformed copper, foreseen to be eventually performed underground at CJPL.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The first detector fabricated from commercial crystal that matches expected performance will be installed at CJPL in 2017.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: This detector enables control of assembly materials placed in its vicinity that are known to be the dominant source of radioactive background, as well as efficient testing of novel electronics and readout schemes.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The benchmark would be the ability to perform light-WIMP searches with germanium detectors having 0νββ-grade background control.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: This configuration would enable detailed studies of potential cosmogenic tritium contamination in germanium detectors, which in turn would allow the exploration of strategies to suppress such background.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The projected sensitivities to χN spin-independent ( Figure 5a) and spin-dependent cross sections ( Figure 5b) for CDEX-1T at targeted specifications in detector threshold, background levels and data size.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The goal of the 0νββ program will be to achieve sufficient sensitivities to completely cover the inverted neutrino mass hierarchy.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: A first 0νββ analysis on the CDEX-1 data was performed, where an upper limit of τ 1 2 > 6.4 × 10 22 yr at 90% confidence level was derived [43].
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: IV.
PANDAX
The PandaX program [3,4] uses xenon as the target and detector medium in searches for WIMP dark matter, as well as 0νββ in 136 Xe isotopes.
body_text.section: IV. PANDAX

body_text.text: The program follows a staged plan.
body_text.section: IV. PANDAX

body_text.text: The first and second stages (PandaX-I and -II) focus on WIMP detection at CJPL-I [3,4], whereas the future PandaX-III (a 0νββ experiment) and -IV (a multi-ton xenon dark matter experiment) will be installed in CJPL-II [4].
body_text.section: IV. PANDAX

body_text.text: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II
Both PandaX-I and -II utilize a so-called dual-phase xenon time-projection chamber (TPC) to study recoil signals from xenon nuclei upon interaction with WIMPs.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: Two types of signals, S1 and S2, are recorded for every event.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: They are produced by scintillation photons and ionization electrons, respectively.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The XENON [44,45], ZEPLIN [46], and LUX [36] experiments have demonstrated that the liquid xenon detector techniques offer exceptional potentials for background suppression and discrimination, as well as scalability to high target mass, leading the WIMP detection sensitivity in a wide mass range.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: PandaX-I and -II share a common infrastructure ( Figure 7) (described in detail in Reference [7]).
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: A passive shield consisting of polyethylene, lead, and copper was constructed to suppress ambient neutrons and γ-rays.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The innermost shield is a vacuum copper vessel that is also a vacuum jacket for the cryostat, as well as a radon barrier.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The cryogenic and gas handling systems [47] store, circulate, and cool the xenon, and have enough capacity for a ton-scale experiment.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: PandaX-I ( Figure 7a) [7,48] was a 120-kg liquid xenon TPC with polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) reflective walls to enhance light collection.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: Its top and bottom photo-multiplier tube (PMT) arrays consisted of, respectively, 143 and 37 PMTs with diameters of 1 and 3 inches that collected the S1 and S2 photons from events originating in the active volume.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The upgrade to PandaX-II ( Figure 7b) includes a new low-background steel inner vessel, an increased liquid xenon target mass of 580 kg, and a total of 110 3-inch-diameter PMTs.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: An additional 48 1-inch-diameter PMTs serve as an active veto in the optically isolated 4-cm liquid xenon region surrounding the outer circumference of the TPC, providing extra power for background rejection [49].
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: Candidate events from χN elastic scattering are selected according to their locations in the central fiducial volume (Figure 8a).
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: In addition, correlations of the S1 and S2 signatures allow differentiation of nuclear recoil events versus electron recoil background.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: Figure 8b shows the log 10 S2/S1 band of potential signal events, along with calibration data with a neutron source.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The PandaX-I experiment collected data for dark matter searches between May and October 2014.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The final results from PandaX-I are presented in Reference [50] with a total exposure of 54 × 80.1 kg • day exposure.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The data distribution was consistent with the background-only hypothesis.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: A profile likelihood analysis was performed with all candidate events and the expected WIMP and background distributions, leading to the exclusion limit of the χN spin-independent elastic scattering cross section shown in Figure 9a.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: At the 90% confidence level, the results are incompatible with the spin-independent isoscalar WIMP interpretation of all previously reported positive signals from the DAMA/LIBRA [30,51,52], CoGeNT [19,20], CRESST-II [53], and CDMS-II-Si [32] experiments.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The bounds on the χN cross section are more stringent than those from SuperCDMS [33] above a WIMP mass of 7 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: Below a mass of 5.5 GeV/c 2 , the results were the tightest reported constraints among all xenon-based experiments.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The upgrade from PandaX-I to PandaX-II was completed in 2015.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The physics commissioning run performed from November to December 2015 obtained a dark matter exposure of 306 × 19.1 kg • day.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The data taking concluded with the identification of a strong 85 Kr background.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The analysis of this data set has been published [49].
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: No WIMP candidates were identified, and a 90% upper limit comparable to the 225-day limit from XENON100 [45] was set.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: PandaX-II resumed physics data taking in March 2016 after a krypton distillation campaign that reduced the krypton level by a factor of 10, leading to an average electron-recoil background of 2 × 10 −3 events/(kg • day)-the world's lowest reported level.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The combined data from the commissioning run and an additional data-taking period from March to June 2016 provide a total exposure of 3.3 × 4 kg • day [54] and represent the largest WIMP search data set to date.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: After the data-quality cuts, the S1 and S2 signal range cut, and the boosted decision tree cut were applied to the collected data, 389 candidates in the fiducial volume were selected from among 2.45 × 10 7 events (Figure 8a).
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: No WIMP candidates were observed (Figure 8b).
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: On the basis of a profile likelihood analysis of all data, an exclusion limit on the spin-independent χN cross section was obtained (Figure 9b).
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: The most stringent limit, 2.5 × 10 −46 cm 2 at a WIMP mass of 40 GeV/c 2 , represents an improvement of more than a factor of 10 from the limit in Reference [49].
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: In the high-WIMP-mass region, the bounds improve by more than a factor of two over the previous most stringent limit from LUX [56].
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: By using the same data set, PandaX-II set new constraints on the spin-dependent χn (Figure 9c) and χp (Figure 9d) cross sections.
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: Compared with other direct detection experiments, PandaX-II has derived the most stringent upper limits on the χN cross sections for WIMPs with masses above 10 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: A. Dark Matter Searches with PandaX-I and PandaX-II

body_text.text: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals
PandaX-II is anticipated to continue physics data taking until 2018, increasing the exposure by a factor of five.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: In parallel, a future PandaX-xT dark matter experiment and a PandaX-III [57] 0νββ experiment are being planned.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: Both experiments will be located in Hall B of CJPL-II, in which a large, ultrapure water pool will be used as shielding for both experiments.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: Figure 6b shows the conceptual layout of the planned experiments.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The PandaX-xT experiment will be a multi-ton dark matter experiment employing the same dual-phase xenon TPC technology as PandaX-I and -I.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: Its ultimate goal is to reach the so-called neutrino floor at a sensitivity of ∼ 10 −49 cm 2 for the spin-independent χN cross section at a WIMP mass of ∼ 100 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The plan of the initial stage of PandaX-xT is to construct a detector with a sensitive target mass of 4 tons of liquid xenon.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The TPC will be of a cylindrical shape roughly 1.2 m in diameter and height, almost a factor of two larger in every dimension in comparison to PandaX-II.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: For the photo-sensor coverage, it will use in total more than 350 3-inch PMTs at the top and bottom.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The powerful self-shielding from liquid xenon will significantly suppress detector-material-related background.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The level of 85 Kr background is also expected to reduce greatly by performing online distillation during the detector operation.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The total background rate is projected to be 0.05×10 −3 evts/kg/day, a factor of 40 lower than the best level achieved in PandaX-II.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: With a 2-year exposure, the sensitivity to the χN cross section is expected to reach 10 −47 cm 2 , more than one order of magnitude lower than the current PandaX-II limit.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: Increasing detector size does increase the technological complexity.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: For example, larger electrodes require new ways to keep their rigidity and flatness when the electric field is applied, while maintaining the thin-wire-plane to ensure high photon detection efficiency.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: As another example, more readout channels and longer readout windows are required, demanding a more sophisticated data acquisition system capable to handle the increasing data bandwidth.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: Therefore, the 4-ton experiment will also serve to demonstrate the critical technology necessary for the future-stage PandaX-xT detector.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: The PandaX-III experiment will search for 0νββ events using high-pressure gas detectors with enriched 136 Xe.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: In the first phase of PandaX-III, a gaseous TPC with 200 kg of 90%-enriched 136 Xe will operate at 10-bar pressure, with a charge readout plane made of microbulk micromesh gaseous structure (micromegas) detectors.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: It will be the first 100-kg stage 0νββ experiment hosted in China.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: In addition to having good energy and spatial resolution, the TPC will be able to reconstruct tracks from 0νββ events, leading to powerful background suppression.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: With a single 200-kg module, the half-life sensitivity to 136 Xe 0νββ decay will reach 10 26 years after 3 years of operation.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: With multiple modules with improved background levels and energy resolution, this program could be upgraded to a ton-scale experiment with a half-life sensitivity of 10 27 years, which would enable the discovery of 0νββ if neutrinos are Majorana fermions with the inverted mass ordering.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: Table II summarizes measurements of ambient radiation background by the main experiment hall in CJPL-I.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: Standard detector techniques [12,[58][59][60] were adopted to perform these measurements.
body_text.section: B. Current Efforts and Future Goals

body_text.text: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES
The residual cosmic-ray flux at CJPL is (2.0 ± 0.4) × 10 −10 cm −2 s −2 or, equivalently, ∼5 m −2 month −1 , measured with two groups of triple-layer plastic scintillator telescopes [12].
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: Owing to the large rock overburden, the attenuation factor of 10 −8 relative to the typical cosmic-ray fluxes on the surface is the largest of all operational underground laboratories ( Figure 2).
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The γ radioactivity from the bedrock, as well as the concrete components of CJPL-I, were measured with a in situ high-purity germanium detector (Table II)  [58].
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The bedrock of Jinping Mountain is mainly marble, providing relatively good radiopurity.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The measured radioactivity levels compare favorably to those of other underground laboratories [10,11].
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The materials used to build CJPL-I were adapted from the construction of the nearby hydro-power station, and no radioactivity screening procedures were performed.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: Consequently, the radioactivity levels of the CJPL-I concrete are higher than those of other operational underground laboratories.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: In the construction of CJPL-II (discussed in Section VI), radioactivity from various concrete samples have been measured, and only those with low radiopurity were selected.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The absorbed dose rate in air is 19.27 nGy h −1 , as determined with a high-pressure ionization chamber.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: This dose rate is lower than typical levels at surface locations.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: Therefore, low-dose-rate calibration for radiation environment dosimetry can be performed at CJPL-I.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The air radon concentration in the main experiment hall at CJPL-I is monitored with commercial ionization detectors.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: During the early operation of CJPL-I from December 2010 to September 2011, the radon concentration was 101 ± 14 Bq m −3 without ventilation, and 86 ± 25 Bq m −3 when the ventilation system was fully operational.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: In 2015, improvements to the ventilation systems resulted in a reduced level of 45 ± 28 Bq m −3 or 108 ± 50 Bq m −3 when the ventilation was on or off, respectively.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: Occasionally, there was a sudden surge of radon concentration to several hundred becquerels per cubic meter despite the ventilation system being fully operational.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The cause of these surges is unknown and is under investigation.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: Neutron backgrounds are measured by multiple detector systems to match their different energy ranges.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: A gaseous 3 He proportional ionization chamber housed in a 100-cm-long tube enables measurements of a thermal neutron flux of (4.00 ± 0.08) × 10 −6 cm −2 s −1 .
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: A 30-L liquid scintillator loaded with gadolinium tags the fast neutron background via delayed coincidence of proton recoils followed by thermal neutron capture, enabling measurements of (1.50 ± 0.07) × 10 −7 cm −2 s −1 in the main hall of CJPL-I.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: A multiple Bonner sphere neutron spectrometer, with 3 He ionization chambers enclosed in polyethylene shielding of different thickness, is used to measure neutron spectra below 20 MeV.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The total flux is (2.69 ± 1.02) × 10 −5 cm −2 s −1 , of which (7.03 ± 1.81) × 10 −6 cm −2 s −1 are thermal (below 0.5 eV) neutrons and (3.63 ± 2.77) × 10 −6 cm −2 s −1 are fast neutrons.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: Neutron measurements are also performed inside the polyethylene shielding room in the main CJPL-I hall.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The thermal neutron flux is (1.75 ± 0.27) × 10 −7 cm −2 s −1 , as determined with a 3 He proportional ionization chamber, whereas the fast neutron flux is (4.27±0.72)×10 −9 cm −2 s −1 , as determined with gadolinium-loaded liquid scintillator.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: These measurements demonstrate that the 100-cm-thick polyethylene room can efficiently attenuate the neutron flux.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: Efficient low-level counting facilities are essential for underground experiments.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: Currently there are two lowbackground counting facilities, GeTHU-I and GeTHU-II, which employ high-purity germanium detectors installed within custom-designed shielding structures [8].
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The best integrated background rate achieved to date is 0.42 counts min −1 (kg • Ge) −1 between 40 and 2,700 keV.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The copper shielding of these germanium detector systems contains residual radioactivity.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: Future upgrades would reduce the background by use of fine radiopure electroformed copper, instead of commercially produced copper.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: The GeTHU systems provide support for the various CJPL experiments.
body_text.section: V. LOW-BACKGROUND FACILITIES

body_text.text: VI.
CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II
The commissioning of CJPL-I and the development of its scientific programs attracted great interest both domestically and internationally.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Construction on the expansion of the facility began in 2014.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Figure 10 depicts a schematic diagram of the second phase of CJPL (CJPL-II).
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The key dimension parameters characterizing access and installation of future experiments are summarized in Table III.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: CJPL-II is located 500 m to the west of CJPL-I, along the same road tunnel.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: It will have four caverns, each with dimensions of 14 m (width) × 14 m (height) × 130 m (length), and will be interconnected with access and safety tunnels.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The laboratory floor area will be approximately 20,000 m 2 .
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Two pits will provide additional headroom for specific applications-one with diameter 18 m and height 18 m and another with length 27 m, width 16 m, and depth 14 m.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The total space, including internal traffic tunnels and common facilities, will be approximately 300,000 m 3 .
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: It is planned that additional ground laboratory, offices, meeting venues and logistics support will be built before 2020 to accommodate 150 scientists to live and work in a campus which is in the neighbourhood of another 600 workers from the hydro-power company.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Excavation of CJPL-II was performed by the drilling and blasting technologies.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The walls are supported by numerous steel bolts while the surfaces are finished by custom-selected low-activity concrete.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The potential problems of underground water were alleviated by numerous embedded 5 cm diameter drain tubes which guide the water into the ground drainage system.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Representative photos during CJPL-II construction are displayed in Figures 11abcd, the context of which are described in the caption.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The available electrical power is 10 MW, provided by the Jinping Power Plant.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Ventilation is crucial for human well-being, equipment performance and radon control.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Fresh air will be brought in from the western entrance of the Jinping Tunnel by three 800 mm diameter PVC (PolyVinyl Chloride) tubes at specified and maximal flow rates of 24000 m 3 /h and 45000 m 3 /h, respectively.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The peak water supply capacity is at 1006 m 3 /h.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The potential science programs at CJPL-II are in various stages of development.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Both CDEX and PandaX have plans to expand and pursue studies of dark matter and 0νββ with detector mass targeted towards the scale of 1 ton germanium and 10 ton xenon, respectively.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The proposed Jinping Neutrino Experiment [62] will study solar and geo-neutrinos [63] with a 4 kiloton liquid scintillator detector, A 1-ton prototype [64] is being constructed.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The approved JUNA (Jinping Underground laboratory for Nuclear Astrophysics) program [65] will benefit from the ultra-low background conditions of CJPL to apply accelerator-based low-energy nuclear physics techniques to directly study for the first time a number of crucial astrophysical nuclear interactions at energies relevant to the evolution of hydrostatic stars.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The experimental setup includes a high current accelerator based on an ECR (Electron Cyclotron Resonance) source [66], advanced detectors, and low-background shielding systems and will occupy half of Hall A of CJPL-II.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The schematic layout is depicted in Figure 6c.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The goals of the first phase of JUNA are the direct measurements of 25 Mg(p,γ) 26 Al, 19 F(p,α) 16 O [67], 13 C(α,n) 16 O and 12 C(α,γ) 16 O cross-sections.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: The experiment will be installed and commissioned on site in 2018 and the initial series of scientific results are expected in 2019.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: As the deepest underground laboratory in the world, CJPL also offers an ideal location to study geo-science.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Plans have been drawn to build an international open research platform at CJPL-II to explore the interaction of deep-rock mechanics with seismology dynamics, to pursue research on in-situ rock-mass testing methods and pressured coring techniques, and on advanced theories on rock mechanics [68].
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: By unveiling characteristics of irregular constitutive behaviors of deep rock, these studies would contribute to safe and efficient excavation of mineral resources and to effective disaster prevention.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: Rock excavation and civil engineering of CJPL-II finished in May 2016.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: When the construction is fully completed, the facility will become available to domestic and international researchers.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: A dedicated task force will be responsible to attend the everyday operation and maintenance of the laboratory.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: An international advisory committee had been setup since 2014 to provide recommendations on the management, operation and potential science programs.
body_text.section: VI. CHINA JINPING UNDERGROUND LABORATORY: PHASE II

body_text.text: VII.
PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK
CJPL, a new underground facility in Sichuan, China, was constructed within a relatively short period of 8 years.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: The location has the deepest rock overburden for cosmic-ray suppression in the world.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: By the time CJPL-II is completed in 2017, it will also have the largest volume of available laboratory space.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: The facility's horizontal drive-in access allows efficient deployment of large teams and equipment.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: The existing surface support facilities benefit from the infrastructure created during the earlier construction of hydro-power projects in the area.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: The facility will contribute significantly to the world's capability to conduct low-count-rate experiments.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: The two first-generation research programs at CJPL-I, CDEX and PandaX, focus on searches for dark matter.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: Competitive results at the world stage have been achieved.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: These projects will continue to evolve in the forthcoming CJPL-II, extending and expanding the scope of their physics programs to include other areas of study, such as 0νββ.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: A new program on low-count-rate nuclear astrophysics measurements, JUNA, is in preparation.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: There remains plenty of space for prospective future users at CJPL-II.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: The science programs are still in the formative stage.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: The facility has attracted a great deal of user interest, both nationally and internationally.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: The   The band of log 10 S2/S1 versus S1 from PandaX-II events within the fiducial volume.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: The red solid line represents the fitted median derived from nuclear recoil calibration data.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

body_text.text: Weakly interacting massive particle candidate signals are those below the median line; no such events were observed.
body_text.section: VII. PROSPECTS AND OUTLOOK

presents a schematic diagram of CJPL-I.

body_text.text: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
The authors thank all of the scientific colleagues and technical staff who contributed to the realization of the facility and science programs reported in this review.
body_text.section: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

body_text.text: Construction and operation of CJPL are financed by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (11355001), and basic facility funding is provided by the Ministry of Education of China.
body_text.section: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

body_text.text: Funding support for the CDEX program is provided by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (11275107, 11355001, 11475117, and 11475099)
